awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Commercialization of A High Throughput Cell Mechanical Stimulator
awd_abstract_narration:
Cell based assays have been widely used for drug discovery, where the effectiveness and toxicity of drugs on live cells in presence of various external stimulations are examined. Lab-on-chip technologies with high throughput capability have greatly propelled the development of cell based assays by significantly reducing the time and cost of applying these stimulations and obtaining the cell responses. Current technologies that stimulate live cells by mechanical signals, however, have relatively low throughput. This project is to explore the commercialization potential of a high throughput cell mechanical stimulator, which applies controlled strain to a large number of in vitro cultured cell groups. The proposed technology provides an important research tool for biological researchers in the field of cellular biomechanics and mechanobiology. 

The high throughput and multiplex capability enabled by the proposed technology meets the imperative needs for parallel application of mechanical stimulation to live cells. Understanding how mechanical signals regulate cell function and how they orchestrate with drugs and medications is therefore a fundamental question that attracts extraordinary attentions of a large number of researchers in universities and pharmaceutical industry. The proposed device is expected to provide a powerful research tool to enhance our understanding of the role of mechanical signals and their synergistic effects with drugs/medications. It is expected to hasten new knowledge in mechanobiology and new treatments against diseases in many fields. It will also allow high throughput screening of drugs and medications that target on treatments of mechanical-activated cells and tissues. The greatly enhanced throughput and lower per-test cost are also expected to expand the market from basic research laboratories at universities to pre-clinical and applied research divisions in pharmaceutical industry.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This NSF I-Corp projects aims at exploring the commercialization potential of a high-throughput cellular mechanical stimulators for cellular mechanics and mechanobiological studies. The team carefully examined the market size and growth of the proposed device, and interviewed 100+ potential customers. The study shows that such research tool has two primary customer segments: the researchers in universities and research institutes and industrial user. The university users care more about the cost and customization, while the industrial users care more about the reliability and throughput. The university users, although low in population, are influential to the purchasing decision of the industrial customers. The findings are applicable to other research tools that have customer segments in both academia and industry and can help to streamline the commercialization pathway of relevant products. Based on the feedback from interviews, the team has revised the device design and started collaboration with biologists in respective biological fields to demonstrate the utility of the device in various research domains. The strategy is to start with university users and identify the minimal variable product that have the largest market share, and then penetrate the market with the help of the endorsement from pilot university users. Meanwhile, the project is successful in training next generation workforce with both solid engineering background and commercialization knowledge. The customer identification and validation approaches have been incorporated in the graduate courses taught by the PI. Several mentees of the PI have won awards in technology entrepreneurship competition at the PI’s institute. The entrepreneur lead from this project is now the program manager that is in charge of the I-Corps@Ohio program.

 

Intellectual Merit:

This I-Corps study confirms that the researchers in the field of cellular biomechanics and mechanobiology need an advanced cell mechanical loading device that can address the problems with current devices. The requirement of throughput varies among the customers: industrial customers ask for high throughput devices, while university customers can tolerate low to medium throughputs with a reasonable cost. The university customers are most concerned about the customization and capability of the device, including the independent control of each loading parameter and the incorporation of other forms of stimulation.

 

Broader Impacts:

Mechanical signal is critical to live cells in a broad array of physiological and pathological events. In many cases, the mechanical signals need to be applied in conjunction with other types of stimulation. This requires customization of the device. During the I-Corps, the teams learns that the customers, especially those at universities or research institutes would like to purchase devices that can address their respective needs, rather than a basic model. Therefore, a device with good compatibility with other types of stimulation is a critical factor for market penetration and is likely to enhance the impact of the device on the market.

 


Last Modified: 04/28/2016
Modified by: Yi Zhao
